FullscreenActivity
GENERAL \n By means of the application you get to know the Museum of Byzantine Culture in Thessaloniki playing an amusing treasure hunt. \n Visit all the rooms of the museum, answer correctly to questions and mobilize all your skill to solve the puzzles you meet.\n Finish your walk in the museum with the highest score.\n\n 1. Follow the clues on the screen \n 2. Use the QR code scanner to identify the right exhibit\n 3. Complete successfully the questions and puzzles to increase your score.
QUIZ GAME\n One question, four possible answers. \n All you have to do is to find the right one.\n How good are you in history?
FILL IT\n Only if you put everything in place you can see what the picture hides.\n A classic puzzle game or else "Fast and neat".
SAVE THE MUSEUMS EXHIBITS FROM DESTRUCTION\n Museum’s exhibits are falling from the sky. Observe the screen, in order to see which exhibit must be saved and try to grab it.\n But be careful not to grab the wrong exhibit. At the end you have the opportunity to learn about this exhibit.
CATCH ME IF YOU CAN\n The faster your reflexes are the better.\n Hit the moving image in order to complete the bigger picture in the end of the game.\n The more successful hits you have you earn points and a better look at one of the masterpieces of our museum..
EACH SEAL HAS TWO FACES\n Can you identify which ones these are?\n Match them as fast as you can to earn points. The more observant you are the faster you finish.\n Remember that nothing ends, if you don’t move from one gallery to another inside the museum.
OBSERVE THE COINS CAREFULLY\n Try to remember the order in which they are illuminated.\n Then select them in this order without doing a mistake
WHERE ARE THE MONUMENTS?\n Knowing the monument and its location can you find where it is located on the map?\n Select the location on the map as close as possible to the monument to earn points.\n TOn the walls of the museum the information you ask for are hiding.
FIND THE PROPER ORDER\n For some of the vessels we admire to this day for their appearance and details took enough effort and time to get their form.\n Enter their stages of production, their name and their form as fast as you can to earn points.
FIND THE PAIRS OF POTTERY\n Someone mixed the museum’s vessels. You have a few seconds to observe and memorize their positions. \n Then you have to use your memory to identify pairs of vessels with the least effort possible.
LIGHTEN THE IMAGE\n The lights went out! To see the image you must turn the lights on.\n Match the cables located at the right of the screen to form a single one, in order that all the lights can be turned on with as little as possible moves.\n Touching each piece of the cable you can change its orientation.
SAVE THE ARCHES\n In fact it’s the classic game of hangman.\n Just find the word before all the arches of the exhibit are demolished.\n What if the words are a bit unusual, notice your environment and it will give you the answer.

The name of the team is Anaptixis Studios and the application was first shown at the International IMCL conference in Thessaloniki in 2015.\n Development Team:\n Dimopoulos Theodoros - Christos\n Kotsikoris Panagiotis\n Moschou Athanasia\n\n

Exhibit information
Fragment of a mural mosaic, of the mid-5th c., depicting a fountain. The mosaic, until recently, was covered by the newer western walls of the central aisle of the basilica of Acheiropoietos in Thessaloniki. On the detached mosaic the lower part of a fountain is depicted in blue color. From the fountain water overflows and drops on leaf sprouts and a bird. The representation is shown on a gold background
Reliquary from Nea Iraklia. Rectangular casket with flat cover, fastened with hooks. Reliefs decorate the four sides of the artefact with themes from the Old and New Testament. On the front side there is the representation of the Giving of the Law by Christ to the apostles Peter and Paul. On the reverse there is the depiction of the Three Children in the furnace. On the narrow sides we have Daniel in the lion’s pit and the Delivery of the Ten Commandments to Moses. Dated to the 4th c.
Amphora of spherical shape with tapered neck which ends in a glass shape mouth. The two arched handles are formed parallel to the shoulders of the amphora. Thin horizontal corrugations made on the potter’s wheel run around the body of the amphora at shoulder height. It comes from the Hosios David of Thessaloniki and dates to 5th-6th c.
On the obverse a bust of Emperor Justinian is shown, in military attire and crusader sphere in his right hand. All around we read the inscription DN IVSTINIANVS PPAVG (Dominus Noster Iustinianus Perpetuus Augustus, which means, our Lord, Justinian, the eternal emperor). Dated to 545-565 AD
The vaulted mural painting with scenes from the Old and New Testament. On a panel, surrounded by red and green band, there is a depiction of the First Created after their disobedience. The representation is organized around a tree with rich foliage, in the trunk of which the snake is wrapped. It derives from Thessaloniki (western cemetery) and it is dated to 360-370 AD
Trapezoforo, i.e. support of a uniped, luxurious table, made of marble. It is adorned with a relief figure in the iconographic type of the “Good Shepherd”, the young shepherd with a ram on his shoulders, who symbolizes Christ. Found in Thessaloniki and dated to the mid 4th c.
Pair of gold bracelets, which are decorated with cloisonné enamel. The tiles alternately depict bird pecking at leaf, palm. They come from Thessaloniki and are dated to 10th c.
Parchment codex, Four-gospel Codex from Thessaloniki. The Four-gospel Codex contains excerpts that are read on Sundays, Saturdays and weekdays in the church. It consists of 325 sheets and is truncated. The text is developed in two columns, with musical signs, written in a meticulous minuscule script that echoes the style of the second half of the 11th and early 12th century. It is illustrated with full-page portraits of the evangelists Matthew, Mark and Luke, whereas the depiction of John has been detached.
On one side, which is the curved one, Christ is depicted young in the type of Christ Emmanuel. He is framed by the inscription IC- XC (Jesus Christ) and around him there is the invocation “+Κύριε βοήθει”. On the reverse side, which is concave, Manuel I is depicted standing, with imperial attire, holding a banner and a crusader sphere. The coin is found in New Panteleimon in Pieria and is dated back to 1164 - 1167 AD. Issued by the mint of Constantinople
On one side emperor Heraclius is depicted on the left together with his son and co-emperor Heraclius Constantine on the right. They both wear mantle and crown with a cross. Among their heads there is a cross. All around there is the inscription ddNNhERACLIUS ЄthЄRACONSTPPAV (Dominus Noster Heraclius et Heraclius Constantinus Perpetuus Augustus), which means “our Lords Heraclius and Heraclius Constantine the Eternal Emperors”. It is dated to 613-630 AD. Issued in Constantinople.
Strainer of hemispherical shape. The entire body of the vessel is pierced. Because the strainer had through the centuries the same use, retained the same shape until nowadays
Castles were fortified settlements, which brought together the basic functions of a city. They were built in key positions and controlled the passes of roads. They also provided protection to residents and residents of the surrounding area in times of war. The limited space and the terrain determined the town planning of the castles and the changes in the architecture of the houses.
Portable, bizonal icon with six saints. On the upper zone the military saints George, Demetrius and the physician saint Panteleimonas are depicted, while on the lower zone the military saints Theodore Stratilatis and Theodore Teron together with saint Antonios are shown. It comes from the church of Agios Athanasios in Thessaloniki and is dated to late 14th-early 15th c.
Large unguentarium, preserved whole and welded. It is made of dark blue glass with free blowing. Supported on a flat unformatted basis. The first spherical body has been pressed and is lenticular. The neck is wider at the base and narrows towards the rim. It is found in Thessaloniki and is dated to 14th-16th c.
Etching of 1804, printed in Constantinople. Hilarion and monks of the local dependency of the monastery of St. Catherine of Sinai payed the cost. The engraving shows the building complex of the monastery. In the perimeter of the etching we have the representation of events from the Old Testament and scenes of the life of St. Catherine, such as the burial of her relics by angels on the top of Mount Sinai
Colored woodcut depicting St. John of the Ladder, printed in 1700 in Lviv of today’s Ukraine. Made for the Monastery of St. Catherine on Mt. Sinai
Portable image “The Adoration of the Magi”. The representation of the adoration is displayed in front of a naturalistic landscape. Mountains, rivers, a lake, a city, a bridge, a watermill. On the left, in front of a building, Virgin Mary with the infant Christ in her arms and Joseph behind her welcomes the three Magi, who come from the right. The elder of them comes first and kneels and together with the two youngest, who stand behind him, offer the gifts to Christ. It is dated back to the early 16th c.
Sanctuary gate, originating from an iconostasis gate with the Annunciation on the upper zone and the apostles Peter and Paul on the lower. The scene of the Annunciation is displayed in front of high buildings. The archangel comes, with a strong gait, from the left and the Virgin projects the right hand as a sign of acceptance of Gabriel\'s message, while she holds a spindle in her left hand. It is dated back to the 15th c.
Musical manuscript (Heirmologion). Book of ecclesiastical music, which comprises formulas, according to which chants and hymns of saints are structured. It is dated back to the 17th c.
Archiepiscopal vestment (sakkos) of Ioannikios, bishop of Melenikon. Silk embroidered with gold and silver threads. On the front side there are vine sprouts with grapes, which end in oval medallions, into which the apostles are depicted. The enthroned Christ Pantocrator and the Annunciation are depicted inside the large central frameworks. Work of Christopher Zefar. It is dated between 1745-1753. On the reverse side the family tree of Christ, known as the “Root of Jesse” is depicted.
Mosaic floor from a triclinium of a residence with zodiac and personifications of months and winds. The mosaic was found in Thessaloniki and is dated to the first half of the 5th c. The subject of the mosaic was very popular in the 4th and 5th century and it is originated from the pagan tradition. Identify South wind.

Oinochoe (ewer) of the 4th century made of pale green glass. The vessel is constructed with the technique of blowing (blown glass) in two consecutive molds Bronze oil lamp, dating to the 6th century, that was found in Louloudies of Kitros in Pieria. The hole, through which they use to fill it with the fuel (usually oil), has a clam-shaped cover. The tip of the wick came out of the second hole. The handle of the oil lamp is cross-shaped and at its back there is a carrying handle. In the centre of the cross there is a link chain, which resulted in another equivalent, in front of the clam-shaped cover, so that the lamp can be hung from above. Clay whistle of the 3rd-4th century. Discovered in the eastern cemetery of Thessaloniki, north of the cemetery of Evangelistria. When the vessel was filled with water, the sound produced, when using the whistle, imitated a bird’s chirping. The sound was varied according to the height of the water level inside the vessel. The format of this game remained unchanged until nowadays, as similar whistles are sold as toys so far, especially at festivals of regions remote from urban centres Wooden portable icon with Virgin dexiokratoussa, which is dated to around 1200. The Virgin Mary is depicted to the waist, praying with her left hand on the chest and keeping with the right hand the infant Christ. Christ blesses with the one hand, while he holds with the other a wrapped scroll (manuscript in the form of a scroll). Glass unguentarium of the 4th century from the Western cemetery of Thessaloniki (which was located in the todays region of Ampelokipi) Glass bracelet of the 10th-12th centuries from Macedonia. It is painted with yellow and gold color. Vertical strips divide the surface of the bracelet into rectangular sections, where alternately bird with long neck (probably swan) and stretched wings and horizontal zigzags are depicted. Archiepiscopal vestment (sakkos) of Ioannikios, bishop of Melenikon. Silk embroidered with gold and silver threads. On the front side there are vine sprouts with grapes, which end in oval medallions, into which the apostles are depicted. The enthroned Christ Pantocrator and the Annunciation are depicted inside the large central frameworks. On the reverse side the family tree of Christ, known as the “Root of Jesse” is depicted. Work of Christopher Zefar. It is dated between 1745-1753. Perperum of Manuel I Comnenus, which is dated to 1164-1167 from New Panteleimonas in Pieria. On one side, which is the curved one, Christ is depicted young in the type of Christ Emmanuel. He is framed by the inscription IC- XC (Jesus Christ) and around him there is the invocation “+Κύριε βοήθει”. On the reverse side, which is concave, Manuel I is depicted standing, with imperial attire, holding a banner and a crusader sphere. Up and right, in the background, there is the hand of God. On the right and on the left of the emperor we read “To Manuel Despot, the Porphyrogenitus”. Issued by the mint of Constantinople Lead seal of emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus (913-959). On one side Christ Pantocrator with the initials IC-XC (Jesus Christ) is depicted. On the reverse side the emperor Constantine VII in bust, with imperial attire, and holding a crusader sphere in his right hand is depicted. We read the partly ruined inscription “+ Constantine”, written in circular form. This is the seal of the erudite emperor Constantine VII, son of Leo VI the Wise. The depiction of the emperor on this seal is an excellent example of a portrait of that era Colored engraving, engraved and printed in 1798 by the monk painter Nikiforos, who came from the town of Karpenissi. Its central theme is St. George, the dragon-slayer and view of the Monastery of Xenophon, which is dedicated to this Saint. The representation is surrounded by secondary small icons in the corners• up and right Christ blessing the great martyr George, before He gives him the crown, and on the left St. Marina praying with a cross in her hand. On the bottom of the depiction we can see the Saint who hits the earth and water flows and his beheading Opus sectile, placed on a wall. Dated to the second quarter of the 7th century it comes from the church of St. Demetrius in Thessaloniki. White and red marble tiles are placed on a background of a different color and form a panel of geometric character. Works of this type are a special kind of luxurious ornamentation, found in buildings of this era Mural painting of the early 5th century from the west wall of a vaulted tomb, depicting the history of Sosanna from the Old Testament. Sosanna was accused of adultery by two Jewish judges, when she refused to give in to their solicitations. After that they both asked the death penalty for her. Sosanna prayed to God, Who sent Daniel to cross-examine the judges and reveal the plot. The theme of the representation was very popular at that time, because it expresses allegorically the triumph of the Church against the heresies which shook the Christian world in the 4th and 5th centuries. Relief slab of a pseudo sarcophagus from a Christian tomb of the 11th-12th century from Thessaloniki. We miss the left half of the slab. The slab was re-used, as it is mentioned in the Hebrew inscription, engraved on the left part of it, in order to cover the tomb of Rabbi Yitzhak Sarouk, who died on Monday, 9 of the month Chesvan, in the year 5375 for the Jews, namely in November 1615. The decoration includes two crosses on pedestals (the horizontal antennas of which have been destroyed, to be used for Jewish burial). The cross on the right is Latin and is surrounded by vines that grow from its base. An eagle on the right and a smaller bird on the left, pecking berries of grapes, step on the vine. The cross on the left is a Resurrection cross (with a double horizontal antenna) and a cypress grows from its base.
Copy of Christos Lefakis of 1950-1960 from a fresco found inside an Early Christian tomb (4th c.) outside the west walls of Thessaloniki in Settlement Tyroloe. It depicts two colorful birds, framing a fruit basket. The background is decorated with flowers. The scene refers to a heavenly landscape, suggesting the afterlife. Thanks to copies of Christos Lefakis we know the decoration of many funerary mural paintings which have not survived, as was the case Book of ecclesiastical music (Heirmologion) which comprises formulas, according to which chants and hymns of saints are structured. It is dated back to the 17th c.
